Award.AwardTitle: OPERATION OF CORNELL HIGH ENERGY SYNCHROTRON SOURCE (CHESS)
Award.AbstractNarration:
Non-technical Abstract
This award from the National Science Foundation to Cornell University supports the operation of the Cornell High Energy Synchrotron Source (CHESS) as a national user facility. User access is granted free of charge through a competitive proposal review process. CHESS provides high energy X-ray beams, for studies including the atomic and nanoscale structure, properties, in operando, and time-resolved behavior of electronic, structural, polymeric and biological materials, protein and virus crystallography, environmental science, radiography of solids and fluids, and micro-elemental analysis.

The synchrotron facility is used by investigators from a wide range of science and engineering disciplines in academia, industry, government, non-profits, and international institutions. CHESS attracts new users through presenations at professional society meetings, a monthly newsletter, and their website. This award also provides support to upgrade the facility and enhance the capabilities of the existing instruments. These upgrades enable CHESS to increase the number users and provide unique capabilities to the research community. Technology development at CHESS on new X-ray extraction devices, detectors, and optics will advance synchrotron science.

CHESS plays a national role in advanced training of X-ray beamline scientists, expert X-ray users; and accelerator scientists. CHESS educates the K-12 students and teachers, community college students, and the public through science activities, after-school science programs, and tours. CHESS has specific initiatives aimed at increasing participation of underrepresented groups in Science Technology Education and Mathematics (STEM) fields with goals of improving science literacy and the national workforce.


Technical Abstract
This award from the National Science Foundation to Cornell University supports the operation of the Cornell High Energy Synchrotron Source (CHESS) as a national user facility for a five year period to advance materials science, condensed matter physics, chemistry, engineering, and biology through advanced uses of X-ray radiation. CHESS will deliver 140 user days per year to 11 beamlines that enable advanced imaging, the determination of atomic and larger scale structure in materials, and various spectroscopies to probe electronic organization and transitions in materials. User access is granted free of charge through a competitive external proposal review process.

CHESS will pursue the following seven collaborative user initiatives, which are expected to drive their respective scientific fields and will guide beamline upgrades: Computationally-Enabled Total Scattering Studies of Complex Materials; Designer Solids: Structure, Processing and Performance; Rapidly Evolving Systems; X-Ray Imaging: Scanning Probe and Full-Field; Spectroscopic Studies; Energy and Structural Materials: In Operando Studies; and, Macromolecules and Biochemistry. This award also provides support for upgrades of the facility, most notably the installation of three Cornell designed undulators, which are an order of magnitude less expensive than current technology. The increased flux from the undulators at 7 of the 11 beamlines will enable new experiments at CHESS such as probing the structure of excited electronic states.

CHESS plays a national role in advanced training of X-ray beamline scientists, expert X-ray users; and accelerator scientists. The Xraise program reaches out to K-12, community college students and public school teachers. Xraise collaborates with other Cornell research centers and local schools to offer classroom science activities, creates and sponsors after-school science programs, and hosts tours and demonstrations for the public in the eXploration Station. CHESS has specific initiatives aimed at increasing participation of underrepresented groups in Science Technology Education and Mathematics (STEM) fields with goals of improving science literacy and the national workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Operation of Cornell High Energy Synchrotron Source (CHESS) - Award Number: DMR-1332208

The Cornell High Energy Synchrotron Source, CHESS, is a high-intensity X-ray source which provides users state-of-the-art synchrotron radiation facilities for research in physics, chemistry, biology, environmental sciences, materials science and even humanities. X-ray techniques are ideal to discover microscopic details that are otherwise invisible to the human eye: High-energy X-ray beams penetrate deep into samples, enabling a look into plants, bones, rocks, soils, cultural artifacts as well as manmade materials such as composites and superconductors. Scientists visiting CHESS are able to map the elemental composition of an object, determine the arrangement of atoms and even monitor how elements change their chemical state over time, e.g. when a battery is charged/discharged or a catalysis enables a chemical reaction. This elemental, structural and/or chemical information is available with micrometer spatial resolution over areas extending several millimeters.

As one of the many examples of CHESS providing unique scientific information using powerful X-rays, we highlight the use of X-ray microscopy at CHESS to investigate the charging and discharging processes in Lithium (Li) batteries.  Li metal has long been considered the ideal anode material for Li rechargeable batteries. In a recent study at CHESS, researchers employed synchrotron-based X-ray imaging methods to image the evolution of Li plating/stripping on the Li metal anode under operando and practical conditions for battery operation. These images they obtained provide detailed insights into the role of critical battery operating parameters, such as Li salts, current density, ionic strength, electrolytes, and additives on dendrite growth. Given the enormous practical potential of Li metal anodes, operando studies using X-ray imaging techniques like this research at CHESS will lead to a deeper understanding of the complex Li plating/stripping mechanism and provide a platform for further development and eventual large-scale deployment of Li metal anodes in rechargeable batteries.

CHESS also supports X-ray facilities for macromolecular crystallography and small angle X-ray scattering to understand the structure and function of so-called macromolecules, i.e. large and heavy molecules that form the building blocks of life. Knowing the atomic arrangement of macromolecules is essential to develop new drugs treating cancer and infectious diseases. Researchers at CHESS used X-ray scattering to characterize the structure of Ribonucleic acid (RNA) which is a macromolecule essential for coding and decoding of genes. Its biological functions depend critically on its structure and flexibility which in turn are dependent on its chemical environment. Cornell researchers used CHESS to quantify substantial and solution-dependent variation in the structure and flexibility of RNA duplexes.

CHESS has trained many X-ray scientists and accelerator physicists who now lead and operate synchrotron facilities around the world. Workshops tailored to introduce participants to the capabilities available at synchrotron sources such as CHESS are an essential part of this effort.  The workshop on "Synchrotron Essentials" held as part of the 2019 CHESS Users Meeting which brought together students from groups under-represented in STEM is an excellent example. Also, every year CHESS offers undergraduate students summer research programs in X-ray science and technology. Summer students work side-by-side with CHESS scientists and staff conducting research on novel battery material, catalysis, and engineered materials as well as developing new X-ray detectors.

During the award period CHESS undertook a major upgrade project, known as CHESS-U funded by New York State. The upgrade involved reconfiguring and optimizing the facility for the production of more intense and highly focused X-rays and the concurrent upgrade of the X-ray experimental stations to exploit the higher X-ray intensities for novel experiments. These enhanced capabilities place CHESS as one of only five high-energy, third-generation synchrotron sources in the world.

CHESS is an internationally recognized leader of innovation in synchrotron technology and methods. CHESS Compact Undulators, CCUs, are complex precise arrays of magnets that create high intensity, high energy X-ray beams at light sources around the world. CCUs are about ten times more compact, lighter, and less expensive than conventional insertion devices. Moreover, since the magnets in CCUs surround the particle beam symmetrically, they provide enormous gains in performance at the next generation, diffraction limited light sources which are now under construction in the USA. Following a successful proof-of-concept design, CHESS scientists have now added a hydraulic-assist driver to further improve device performance.

State-of-the-art experimental facilities, a culture of enabling difficult experiments and the tireless development of novel X-ray technology and methods combined with a commitment to training future synchrotron scientists make CHESS a unique facility in the world where the scientific community can execute experiments that simply cannot be done anywhere else.
